conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (E or F) the liquid from streams A, B, C, and D will flow into after passing through baffles.
Streams A, B, C, and D are the starting points of the liquid.
E and F are the containers at the bottom of the image that receive the liquid.
Streams B and C strike the red slanted barrier and are deflected to the left together.
Stream D hits the purple slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
Stream A straddles the angle of the black baffle and splits into two branches.

premise: Streams B and C strike the red slanted barrier and are deflected to the left together. Stream D hits the purple slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
conclusion: Streams B, C, and D strike the black slanted barrier, merge, and are deflected to the right.

premise: Stream A straddles the angle of the black baffle and splits into two branches. Streams B, C, and D strike the black slanted barrier, merge, and are deflected to the right.
conclusion: The mixture of streams A, B, and C separates into containers E and F equally, while stream D ends in container F.
